review_title: Has the best culture, growth opportunity and overwhelming amount of learning
pros:
* Best of it's culture, you're always respected, very inclusive, and always takes it serious when it comes to any degradation of individual or group.
* Enormous growth opportunity. You definitely reap what you sow. Invest your time in learning and picking up new challenges and you will see amazing things with your growth within the organization.
* Overwhelming amount of Learning. There's so much of learning materials (You'd hope that you had all the time in the world to complete those). Coaching and Mentoring comes easy as people are always willing to do it without any disparity.
cons:
* Very process oriented organization but that's understandable as it's a huge matrix organization.
* Change is the only thing that never changes - happens too often at times (You have to keep up with it).
* Organizational changes can affect your employment. (But you're always given the option for internal movements for any available vacancies which fits your profile and experience)

job_title: User Experience Designer in Markham, ON
pros:
Benefits were very good, especially for mental health coverage.
Free parking and EV charging
Decent starting salary 
Flexible work schedule
cons:
Toxic work environment with management. 
Organization often “switched gears” in vision, resulting in wasted designs/work. It felt like the product teams had commitment phobia when it came to seeing through project work. 
Managers/ execs would often talk down to subordinates or be very passive aggressive. 
Politics were unbelievable! Lots of strange things happening behind the scenes around promotions and pay raises.
Bonuses are practically non-existent unless you push for a good deal when you are hired. Don’t expect much in terms of salary increase moving forward.
The lab that I worked at is in the middle of Markham… the commute really sucks unless you live nearby.

review_title: A great place to kick-off your career
job_title: Technical Sales Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros:
So many opportunities to contribute, learn, and grow. 

So many people willing to help and mentor you. 

IBM is full of resources, knowledge, and willingness to invest in your growth - sometimes it can be due to inefficiencies/the size of the company, but that's for you to take advantage of!!

Work-life flexibility and you decide your own hours. Obviously, it would be recommended that you know how to manage yourself and your own career- if you are inexperienced here, you have resources, but this is a role that requires a lot of self-starting, self-learning, and self-managing.

Overall an INCREDIBLE place to work, great company ethics, and just a really old company reinventing itself again. Take advantage of the perks and lessons you can learn and it's an awesome ride. Work here for at least 4-5 years to get a full corporate experience.
cons:
A great experience or terrible experience is often due to someone's manager/the people in their corner - so it's so imperative that a young person understands how to build their own support community and find more seasoned and older people who are there to guide and support them - mentally, intellectually, and emotionally. 

Politics are a big part of the company because it's so big. This is applicable to all corporate companies though, so don't think taking a pay cut to work for Amazon in the same role will change that.

Can be hard to "break into" opportunities as an early professional because of the stigma around new hires - often need to be very persistent, creative, and a driver (which can often lead to young people feeling burnout, disheartened, unheard, and ignored). Which directly translates to the next con: a lot of young people leave very soon after joining. 

It takes about 2-3 years for an average young professional right out of college to understand and navigate the politics, frustrations, and general challenges of the corporate world. IBM follows this timeline fairly well - would be great if this process wasn't so long - it explains the young person attrition.

review_title: Great place to work and to learn
pros: I started working at IBM as an intern and it's been almost 7 years of work in total. Throughout this journey there was no lack of incentives for me to be a better employee every day. We have a series of initiatives that appeal to all types of people. Here I have mentors, coaches, I take courses on everything I want, I have contact with people from all over the world and I am often recognized for the work I do. The company has a very strong culture and values that are put into practice every day. There is great care in promoting a healthy work environment and a sense of belonging for each employee. IBM is like a mother!
cons: The remuneration is good, but it is not among the best in the market. The work is hard, often requiring overtime. Although it is a technology company, the tools we use in my sector (Q2C) are old and manual and always demand innovations for them (when the best solution would be to change them all at once). There is great pressure on quartile closings.Lots of bureaucracy in processes that should be simple. There is a huge fear that someone will do something wrong, which often creates the need for many approvals for anything you have to do, multiplying the execution time and making the changes that really matter difficult.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Working hours can be flexible since a lot is done remotely (but you will work A LOT of hours). Access to a lot of quality on-line education (if you have time to do it after you finish working A LOT of hours).
cons: Not enough focus on giving people time for career development. Aggressive (sometimes unreasonable) schedules/deadlines for projects. Constant reorganizing of teams and resource actions (lay-offs) leaves many teams understaffed and lacking skills for achieving success. Employees are no longer treated with respect from upper management. Team reorganization and technical decisions are make without consulting the people below actually doing the work in many cases. Most jobs are going to the "low cost geos" like India for example. You may benefit from working in IBM for a while, but long term, be prepared to burn out.

review_title: Well compensated but overweight on personal responsibility
pros:
IBM is a historic company and trying to turn a new leaf with a younger workforce and recent acquisitions/divestitures. The overwhelming majority of managers use the "as long as you get your work done, we don't care how you spend your time" guiding principle. This flexibility has been a lifesaver during the pandemic, where working from home has been anything but a walk in the park.
The compensation appears to be above market and I feel appreciated for my work. The benefits package is a bit underwhelming but made up for in base salary.
cons:
A company this large can be hard to navigate. We live and work entirely in TLA's (three letter acronyms) and knowing them all is a point of pride for some. Getting acclimated takes time and requires individual effort to break silos between teams who should be more communicative with each other.
IBM places a lot of responsibility on individual contributors to complete projects and often makes last-minute decisions that change the trajectory of our outcomes. If you're not married to your work, you'll be fine.

pros: The IBM name still resonates with the older people in the IT market. Usually has good training, basically you can get any virtual training you want.
cons:
There are constant layoffs and unfortunately most talent has left the company. IBM lost the cloud game and is constantly shrinking. Best leaders and employees left to work at new generation companies. Company strategy doesn't make sense.

Salaries and benefits are low in comparison to competitors. Promotion is very hard. Salary raises are usually below inflation levels. Benefits have diminished over the years, for example, the BES contribution is laughable.

The company car plan is outrageous, even if your job requires daily use of a company car, IBM charges you up to 2500TL monthly on the rental car. No proper gas or OGS plan, you basically need to pay them and then get reimbursed.

It feels like you constantly need to fund the company, just like the car, there are a lot of things you need to pay out of your own pocket. For example, when I left, lunch allowance was 15TL/day, which is ridiculously low.

review_title: Pros and Cons of working at IBM
job_title: CEO Diretor Executivo in Campinas, São Paulo
pros:
Disclaimer: A lot of what I'm writing below of course depends on the work area and management chain. But I found this to be fairly pervasive policies in IBM in my 9+ years with the company.
1. IBM's policies and management are very flexible when it comes to working remotely or accommodating various life situations (sick days, doctor visits, etc.). Management is encouraged to measure an employee by their work and impact, and not by hours spent at their office.
2. Great colleagues! Though unfortunately, many have been leaving due to the instability of IBM's HW development business.
3. At least in my area, there's a high level of flexibility on which projects should I undertake based on my and my management assessment of business impact.
cons:
Unfortunately, IBM still uses the "normal distribution" rating system, where at the end of the year each employee is ranked as a top contributor (5%), above average contributor (15%), average contributor (~75%), and bottom contributor (5%). This curve is difficult to apply in the R&D world, where you may have many members of the team working long and hard hours, and end up being "average contributors" at the end of the year, because there just isn't room for all to be top contributors.

2. The above may not be so disturbing, if only IBM didn't practically cancelled all raises, performance bonuses and incentive for the non top-performers. I've had a consistent "above average" rating in the last 4-5 years, and my raise and performance bonus were ridiculous mere 1.5-2% of my salary. Were I rated "average contributor" I would have gotten NOTHING. So you can imagine that people can go year after year without any raise to their salary.

From talking to manager friend, this is IBM's way to eliminate the non-top-performers without having to fire them, as part of its direction of reducing US manpower.

3. Hiring freeze in many areas - again, as part of IBM's attempt to reduce its workforce across North America and Europe we see many jobs move to the India and Far East markets. This is of course upsetting to see local teams shrink and disappear, especially when many great local IBM colleagues and experts begin to drop out. From my experience thus far working with India SW teams - they are still very far away from the standards I would have expected from US and Europe based teams.

4. Poor top down communication about company's and divisions' future. Employees learn from rumors and news websites what's about to come...

pros:
IBM provides unlimited WFH that is actually good. But do not get over-exicited reading this! Even this can depend on your manager ;)
Working in b-shifts and c-shifts are less
Women are provided cabs from 7 pm onwards to reach home safely if you get approval from your project to bear the cost
IBM provides unlimited sick leaves which no other organization has
There is no stringent 9 hours work policy. No swipe-in and out policy to record your working hours. Complete your work with no defects and you are good to go :)
Work life balance is good
cons:
IBM is not recommended if you are joining as a fresher. The opportunity to grow within the organization being a fresher and working at the most lower band is minimal. Exceptions can happen - ‘You are lucky if you get a good lead and manager’
You don’t get any perks for your hardwork. Poor pay package, almost no onsite for band 6
The company policies (for hike,onsite,band progression) are not very transparent and no scope to contact your HR. Your only hope is your People Manager. Your future in IBM is in the hands of your manager.

pros: It is a very process-driven company with very competent management in charge. It is a place where one only needs to think about his area of specialization and the delivery of service. The rest is entirely taken care of by the management and the AI-driven infrastructure in place. The well-being, safety, and security of the employees are of the biggest priority to the management and I have felt it to the best during the pandemic period at its peak. It is a place where one can choose his career options, learn, and take up new things and challenges for growth at any time. The company also encourages everyone to learn new things in a very healthy and competitive environment. Learning initiatives are encouraged by the organization at any time and given due credit. In addition to that, the facilities provided by the management is of the highest degree and is the best in the industry. I am very happy here in my associaltion of nearly a year with this esteemed organization. The best part of the whole experience is that the management also ensures that in addition to the employee, the family of the employees is given the best security and safety in all respect.
cons: I have experienced nothing as such here.

pros:
A lot of material to learn new technologies.

Different career plan programs, including IBM roadmaps and coaching, may meet people from other countries. You could work in a multicultural team.

Certifications paid for by IBM.

Good benefits.
cons:
Malinchismo and, sometimes, class discrimination.

It is not easy to move between business units to find a good plan for professional growth. You will not have any chance if the business unit does not want you to leave, although another business unit asks you to work in it, where you earn a better salary and learn the latest technologies. The best thing would be for you to have the right contacts to achieve a great professional growth plan.

There are some projects where the work-life balance is complicated due to poor project planning and organisation. There are other projects where the balance between personal and work life is perfect.

pros:
1. Good opportunities for young people
2. Good exposure to a massive multinational corporation
3. Broad client base in several industries
4. Good learning /skill management system 
5. Good WFH, inclusion and diversity policies
6. Worldwide opportunities for those keen to move
7. High integrity at the core values
cons:
1. Salary is lower than market average
2. Ridiculously small salary increases
3. Nebulous promotion criteria (more politics than merit) that changes often (and you are always behind)
4. New hires make more money than people with same skills and responsibilities (no much financial reward on experience/skills developed) - If you've accepted a lower salary when hired, you will most likely take 10+ years to fix it (most people leave within 2 years)
5. Not the better reputation in Australia (company) and lots of bad attitude from client staff, independent contractors and even ex-IBMers
6. Lots of "clans" and political animals who survive (and make lot of money) just "talking their way" and doing very little.
7. Unfortunately not the company people think it is (not anymore)
8. No matter what extraordinary contributions you've made during your time, you may be made redundant at any time without any compelling reason (or explanation)

Lack of growth and communication of leadership team, and got no idea what going on at ground levels. They failed to understand their employees. Client is God attitude.Even if you got selected to different project, Management will not leave you.. they will ask to server 90 Days within process and then move on(btw its not written anywhere in their policies).If you want to leave IBM before 90 days notice period you have to BEG or Lick. Nothing happens with formal requests or explanation . Recruiter in IBM itself doesn't wait for 90 to join within. Anyways you can join IBM but not the domestic process. Employees who are working in domestic 
process are dead inside. DON'T JOIN DWS !

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good place to start and develop your early career, some smart and dedicated colleagues, decent pay when you start your career, possibilities to grow until certain point if you know how to network with the right people at the right time.
cons: Promotion can sometimes take ages even if you deserve it before, at some point the wages are not competitive compared to most of tech companies in Dublin, not a clear career path, benefits very limited, you basically pay for everything except for an inside doctor that is in the office a couple of days a week, and uncertainty around where the company is going that made many employees leave including myself.

pros: It is an ocean of varied opportunities. If you really wish to experiment and make a career, then the support is immense. Both resources and mentors are always in plenty.
cons: Loads of bias, conscious and unconscious, seen in some Leaders, especially the ones who preach about culture, diversity and inclusion. Waiting to see how IBM transforms these leader so they do not have negative influence on the rest.
